slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="During the COVID-19 pandemic, faculty had to change many of the ways they used to teach in the classroom to adapt to new policies and safety measures. As we return to a new sense of normalcy, its important to recognize that students and faculty will face new challenges and opportunities as they return to campus. Among these changes include new modalities of teaching, the requirement of teaching and learning with masks in the classroom, and new supplies you need to bring with you when you teach on campus.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the hands to learn more about each of these changes.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the sections, a GO button will appear which will take you to a summary and a quiz for this section." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Learning in a post-COVID environment also brings new challenges for students. Click on each of the pictures to learn about the challenges you and your students will face and a few strategies to address each of them.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youve viewed each of the challenges and strategies, a BACK button will appear, which will take you back to the Teaching at HCC Post-COVID slide.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Personal Space
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Because of the social distancing required during COVID-19, personal space bubbles may be a little larger than they were before. This means students may be a little more reluctant to sit as closely to one another and even you as the instructor may need to keep slightly more distance between you and your students.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Avoid crowding by doors and laptop carts by calling on tables or rows to pick up resources or exit the classroom so that students dont all go to the same place at once.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To make sharing documents and collaborating on projects more comfortable, utilize digital tools such as Google Docs, Slides, and Jamboard for collaboration and discussion. This way students can all view and edit the same document without needing to gather around one piece of paper.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="As instructors, we sometimes like to get close to students to offer our help. However, you can avoid hovering over students to see their work by asking them to share a copy with you online via Google Drive, take a picture and send it to you by email, or submit work on Canvas so you can provide feedback.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the Challenges and Strategies slide.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Participation
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Since masks may muffle students voices, they may need to speak a little louder than usual, which can make them more hesitant to participate and answer questions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To mitigate this issue, consider adding a backchannel chat to your classroom where students can type and send in their questions as messages. Tools like Padlet or Canvas Chat can facilitate a backchannel so you can address questions and comments as they come in or wait until a specific time to hold a Q&A session.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Students may also be less likely to speak up and ask for clarification, so consider incorporating polling software like Poll Everywhere, Quizizz, or Socrative to check for understanding. These tools utilize cell phones or computers so that students can type their answers and answer anonymously to further lower the stakes of speaking up.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, where applicable, allow students to write or type their answers either digitally or on mini-whiteboards to gain more participation from the entire class while also allowing students to answer without pressing them to speak louder.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the Challenges and Strategies slide.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Community
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In addition to the increased personal space, masks further complicate the challenge of getting to know peers, since students cant see each others faces, and it may be harder to hear and easier to misunderstand their classmates. Masks may also dampen some of the informal conversations that happen before, during, and after class between students.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Consider asking students to post a picture of themselves on Canvas without a mask so that you and their classmates can see what they look like. You may also consider asking students to post another picture with a mask so that you can associate what they look like with what you will see in the classroom.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Similarly, you may want to use a tool like VoiceThread or Flipgrid to have students create introductory videos without a mask and tell the class a little about themselves. At the end of the video, ask students to put their mask on so that you can also recognize them with their masks. Doing a video yourself will serve as a demo and let students get to know you without a mask as well.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In order to help build classroom community, consider building in activities to help students get to know each other. Have students collaborate either digitally or in person on assignments and projects and incorporate group work into each class meeting so that students have the chance to talk to at least one of their peers each class meeting. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the Challenges and Strategies slide." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Does the material of the mask affect sound or comfort more?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study, or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="True or False: You dont know how your mask fits until you speak for a while with it on. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study, or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="True or False: Professors in the study found face shields are far preferable to masks for speaking. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Click STUDY to refer back to the study or click SUBMIT to check your answer." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Teaching with masks does not have a one-size-fits-all solution. Test out different types of masks to find whats most comfortable for you. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Make sure to bring extra masks so that you can switch between them if it gets too hot or wet while teaching. Having a couple fresh masks will make it more comfortable to teach longer class periods. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While the professors in the study found that face shields are not the holy grail, they still may serve a purpose in classes where facial expressions are essential to learning. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally, experiment and practice teaching with your mask on to find what works best for you. Dont let the first day of class be the first day you try teaching with a mask.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Teaching at HCC Post-COVID slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Using a mask is an important safety precaution for preventing the spread of COVID-19. While teaching in a mask does have its disadvantages, wearing a mask is required for both faculty and students while in the classroom and inside buildings on campus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Face shields may be a good alternative in disciplines like language where seeing facial expressions is important to the learning process. However, masks are still strongly encouraged, and faculty may switch between wearing a face shield and a mask, depending on the activity. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The most important way to prepare yourself to teach with a mask is to practice. Try giving a 5-to-10-minute lesson while wearing a mask so that you can get comfortable with the feeling and experiment with what works best. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Recording yourself or practicing with a friend or family member can provide feedback so that you can adjust your teaching style to be as clear and understandable as possible while wearing your mask. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Which modality does not meet at all in real time? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Select ALL that apply, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Congratulations!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You have completed this section of the New Faculty Crash Course! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next section on Adult Learning Theory! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Try Again.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the RETRY button to take the quiz again. You must get at least 60% to pass. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Community college students are a diverse population and include students from all ethnicities, backgrounds, ages, abilities, and socio-economic statuses. Students attend community college for a variety of reasons, and while many go on to pursue a 4-year degree, community colleges offer many different types of programs, such as career track associate degrees, certificates, and continuing education classes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="However, the one thing all community college students share is that they are adult learners. Each of your students will enter your classroom with unique experience, skills, and needs, but they all should be treated and taught as adults. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this section, we will learn about the demographics of a community college and how those demographics may affect your teaching approach.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Then, well explore 4 principles of adult learning that will help you better engage your students and teach adult learners more effectively. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to get started. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="By keeping the doors to higher education wide open, community colleges have accepted the responsibility for educating all of their students, including those who are not ready to do college-level work. Deepa Rao
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Community colleges in the United States have an Open Door policy, which means that anyone who wants to study at a community college can do so by filling out the application and providing a copy of a high school diploma or GED certificate. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="But what does that mean for you? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="During your time teaching at HCC, you will get students who are taking developmental classes, students with disabilities, military veterans, non-traditional students returning to school, and, of course, you will see some traditional-aged students who have just graduated high school.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Keep in mind that even though all of your students are in college, not all of your students have been well-prepared to do college-level work. Sharing study strategies and getting to know students individually to find out their strengths and weaknesses can help your students build skills, not just for your discipline, but for their entire college career. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Now lets learn more about community college students by playing a game!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Lets play the Percent is Right!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="You will be asked a series of questions about community college student demographics. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Decide on a number or percentage to answer each question and type it in the given field. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Get as close as you can to the right number without going over. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="When youre ready to start, click PLAY to begin. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="What percentage of the Howard county population does not speak English as their native language at home?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Type your answer in the yellow box, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For the last activity in our game, you will be asked to match the numbers on the right to form the correct percentage of each community college demographic on the left.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Drag and drop the numbers into the slots on the left to form 2-digit percentages for each demographic.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Then click SUBMIT to check your answers." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Malcolm Knowles was one of the most famous educators who studied adult learning and coined the term Andragogy, which is a combination of pedagogy and adult, meaning the practice of teaching adults. Although Knowles has many important books, theories, and research, lets look at just four of the principles he used to define adult learning and how they impact adult learners. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the tabs to learn more about each principle. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the tabs, a GO button will appear, which you can use to view a summary and test your understanding with a short quiz on this section. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Involvement
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners want to be involved in their learning process and the planning and evaluation of instruction. They want to be able to make decisions about how they learn, when they learn, and what they learn. In order to involve students in the learning process, incorporate choice into your assignments and materials to give adult learners more agency and ask students for feedback on how their learning is going and what changes can be made to make the class more effective. Explain why you are doing things the way you are doing them and why specific content is being taught. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Experience
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="One of the major differences between teaching children and teaching adults is that adults come into the classroom with a wide range of experiences that can be drastically different from one another. Fortunately, you as an instructor can leverage this experience to put the subject matter into context your students can understand, which can be beneficial for all students in the classroom. Before explaining a topic or concept, check with students to see what they already know about the subject. How far can they go on their own? Once you find the limit of their knowledge or gaps in their understanding, build from that point, instead of starting from scratch. And, you dont have to do all the work! Ask students to come up with their own examples of concepts or similar situations that they may have encountered in their lives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Relevance
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners are most interested in learning topics that they can put into practice right away. Adult learners want to know why the content matters and how it will help them in their everyday lives, either at work or personally. To help adult learners find relevance, explain connections between content and real-world situations. Similarly, ground content in real-world examples to establish how professionals in your discipline need the skill or knowledge to be successful. You can also ask students to find their own relevance in your content by challenging them to reflect on how your material relates to their own personal or professional lives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Problem-Centered
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Adult learners respond better when learning material to solve a problem, instead of learning it for the sake of the curriculum or content. Framing your content in the context of a problem can provide both relevance and real-world situations, while also asking learners to rely on their prior experience to attempt to solve the problem. Using techniques like case studies and scenarios can present course concepts in a more meaningful and engaging way, while also establishing relevance. Give learners a chance to attempt to solve the problem before providing instruction or guidance. Research on prediction shows that students are more receptive to receiving instruction when they have struggled first themselves, and this can also help students identify gaps in their own knowledge, which further establishes a sense of urgency and relevance as they need to know this information. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="True or False: All community college students should be treated as adults, regardless of their age" /> <Span Text="." /> <Span Text=" " /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this section, you will learn about 3 important pedagogical concepts that will help you ensure that you are meeting your course objectives; balancing your technology use, pedagogy, and content knowledge effectively; and reaching and engaging all of your students.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Which of the assessments would be the most authentic for the following objective: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="According to Backward Design, what is the main purpose of having students read the textbook?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="True or False: Backward Design is a linear process that must be followed in a precise order to be effective.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Backward Design is a planning method that can help you plan curriculum, courses, or individual lessons and activities.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="The 3 steps of Backward Design are identifying your objectives, designing assessments that will provide evidence of students ability to meet those objectives, and creating learning activities that will give students the information and practice they need to perform well on those assessments. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Objectives should be clear, and assessments should be authentic. An authentic assessment mimics what students would actually do with the information or skills in the real world. How would you use the skill or knowledge within your discipline, and how would you know youre doing it well? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Your textbook can and should play an important role in your course, but you dont need to follow its organization or use it in its entirety for it to be useful. Identify what your textbook does well and leverage it for that, but if there are gaps or additional information or skills not covered in there, make sure to add those into your course in other ways, such as supplementary materials, videos, projects, or practice assignments.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Backward Design is NOT a linear process, and you may go back and forth between your objectives, assessments, and activities frequently in order to make strong connections between each of them. This is a natural part of course design, and revision and review can help you make stronger connections and more relevant assessments and assignments.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingAfter="0" /> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Pedagogical Concepts slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Imagine you have just printed out a 4-page document and wanted to keep the papers together. Which technology would you choose to make sure your papers stayed together?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While all of the technologies pictured on this slide could help you achieve your purpose, you might have selected one or two clear choices over the others. Yes, maple syrup would technically get the job done, but it may cause other unintended consequences, like not being able to pull the papers apart neatly or having your document invaded by hungry ants. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Its the same principle when it comes to teaching technologies. While some options may technically get the job done, they may make the task more difficult or have unintended consequences. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this section, we will explore a pedagogical framework called TPACK, which will help you balance when to use technology and help you decide which technology to use to meet your learning objectives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The TPACK framework consists of Technology, Pedagogy, and Content Knowledge and describes the transactional relationship and overlaps between these three areas. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="TPACK is the intersection of the appropriate use of technology, good teaching practices, and expert-level content knowledge. The center of these three circles symbolizes the ideal teaching approach that balances these three areas appropriately and is neither too heavy on any one of these areas nor does it leave any of them out. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are also overlaps between each circle that can be helpful in understanding the relationships within the framework. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The overlap of Technology and Content Knowledge challenges us to think about how technology can be used to present content but also to think about how our content may change as new technologies evolve. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The overlap of Technology and Pedagogy asks us to consider how technology can be used to teach but also that as we incorporate new technologies into our classes, we must also teach our students how to use these technologies efficiently and effectively. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, the overlap of Pedagogy and Content Knowledge reminds us that we should not only stay up to date with our own subject matter, but also with the evolving research of teaching and learning and use best practices to present our content and help our students learn and practice it. The flip side of this relationship asks us to remember that many of our students are new to studying our discipline and can benefit from our experience using discipline-specific strategies to read, study, and think within the subject area. We should help our students think like a mathematician or read like a biologist. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more about how you can use the TPACK framework to evaluate and select technologies for classroom use." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="A quick Google search for teaching technologies will present you with an array of tools with shiny new features that you may be tempted to incorporate into your classes to increase engagement and make learning more fun. While you can always reach out to the staff at the Center for Teaching Excellence for guidance, what can we take from the TPACK framework to help us select and use technology effectively in the classroom?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="First, all technology you use should have a clear purpose and relate back to at least one objective or learning goal. Technology should never be used just for the sake of trying something new or for the sole purpose of making the class fun. Having fun in class is not a bad thing, but it shouldnt be the main reason youre using a new tool. Your technologies should accomplish a part of helping you meet your objectives, whether its presenting content, low-stakes assessment, communicating with students, or facilitating group work. Well explore some of the different technologies you can use to do these things in the next section on Teaching Technologies, but for now, its important to make sure whatever the technology is, its pulling its weight in helping you and your students meet the course objectives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In some disciplines, there are specific technologies or tools that professionals use in the field that students may benefit from using. Giving students experience with real-world technologies can give them a leg up when applying for jobs or internships. In addition to technical tools, popular technologies and software used for communication or office tasks may also benefit students who learn to use them in college. Professional communication apps like Slack or Jira may be useful for students to start using before they get to the workplace, and other tools like the Microsoft Office Suite or Google App Suite can be essential skills for students entering the workforce. If there are certain tools you frequently use in the discipline that lend themselves to student use in your class, it can be a great benefit to students to start using these tools now, rather than learn it when they get hired. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Its important to mention that learning new technologies isnt always straightforward and simple. Some technologies are very complex, and while they may have some strong benefits, there is a steep learning curve to get you up and running. Its important to be realistic with the time you have to dedicate to learning a new technology, and if its going to take you hours and hours to learn how to use it effectively, the benefit of using the technology had better be worth it.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Besides the time it takes you to learn the tool, you should also be prepared to teach students how to use the tool if they are going to be expected to use it themselves. Some tools, like presentation software, may not be necessary to teach students how to use if its mainly to present content to them. However, if students are expected to use the technology to complete an assignment or practice a skill, they may require training and guidance to be successful. Fortunately, there are many video tutorials for how to use most technologies online on YouTube. You can also create your own tutorials or demonstrate how to use the tool to students in class, but you should be prepared to answer questions about the technology or help troubleshoot if something isnt behaving as expected for students. The Center for Teaching Excellence can support you by creating instructional documentation for students and even visiting your classroom (in person or online) to give guided instructions or answer questions if that would be helpful to you and your students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The Learning Commons is also available to help students with questions about technology needed to complete assignments. Students can contact LC@howardcc.edu for help, and Learning Commons staff will set up a time to meet with a student by phone or Zoom or provide assistance via email. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click BACK to return to the Pedagogical Concepts slide." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Universal Design for Learning (or UDL) is an approach to teaching that strives to level the playing field and give all learners the opportunity to succeed. It encourages us to teach in ways that appeal to different learning preferences and use multiple strategies and methods to help students meet the learning objectives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Within UDL, there are 3 main areas that provide guidelines for how best to reach your students. These 3 areas of UDL are Engagement, Representation, and Expression. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click on each of the images to view more information about each area. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You can also click the link at the bottom of the screen to visit the CAST website, which provides an even more thorough overview of what each of these areas are and how you can use them to help your students learn. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When you have viewed all 3 of the UDL areas, a BACK button will appear on this slide that will take you back to the Pedagogical Concepts slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Engagement
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Engagement in UDL is all about the WHY of learning. In order to engage all of your students, its important to first establish relevance in what you are teaching. If you think back on our discussion on adult learning theory, you will remember that establishing relevance is also a key part of teaching adult learners effectively. Students want to know why they are learning the content and how it will impact their personal and professional lives. Beginning lectures and activities with real-world examples and helping your students make personal connections to your topic will set them up for greater success. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Next, its important to clearly express your objectives. What is it that you want students to do? Youve already got them interested by establishing how the topic is relevant to them, but you need to also tell them what your expectations are and what skills or knowledge they will be able to demonstrate by the end of the lesson. This helps students focus on the important parts and distinguish between essential information and things that are nice to know but not critical to the objective. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Once you have established relevance and expressed your objectives, try to minimize distractions as much as you can. Usually when we think of distractions, laptops, cell phones, and social media come to mind. However, in this case, distractions can also take the form of unnecessary information, too many additional resources, and even the amount of links on a webpage. Whenever possible, limit your resources and reading to the essential information and consider ways to simplify what your students see, both in class and online. Taking the less is more approach for words and images on a PowerPoint slide can lower cognitive demand and make it easier for students to focus on whats important. And, when youre not using the presentation, blank the screen or turn off the projector to help students focus on the task at hand.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another aspect of engagement is the encouragement you provide to your students. Let students know that you care about them and want them to succeed. It can be as simple as adding a positive message on assignment feedback or stating at the beginning of the semester, both in your syllabus and in person, that you believe in your students and will work with them to help them succeed in your class. That doesnt mean youre going to make things easier for them, but if they work hard and put in the time and effort, you will do the same to help them learn and meet the objectives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Finally, consider providing opportunities for self-assessment and reflection. Incorporate pauses for reflection in lectures and videos and build in self-assessment questions as part of your daily or weekly routine. Ask students to assess how they studied for your class as well as self-assess their understanding of the material. Giving students time and space to reflect and assess can help them think about their own learning process and open the door for conversation about study skills and approaches, which will help them not only in your class, but for their entire college career. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Representation
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Representation refers to the WHAT of learning. What are students learning, and how is it being presented to them? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The most common strategy for enhancing representation is varying your presentation methods. Offering audio alternatives for visual information and offering visual alternatives for auditory information can make your content more accessible to everyone. The key here is less about mixing materials, such as using visual materials one day and then using auditory materials the next, but rather including both options in everything you do. This includes providing transcripts and captions for videos and providing videos or audio clips that explain whats written in text. Its not always feasible to provide alternatives for every piece of content, assignment, or communication, but being aware of which methods you are using and providing alternatives when it is feasible can help make your course more accessible to all of your learners.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another representation strategy is clarifying symbols, keywords, and acronyms that are commonly used in your discipline. Knowing these symbols and acronyms may greatly help students in their future careers. However, you should not expect that all students will come to your class knowing what they mean. This is especially true in math and hard sciences, where specific vocabulary becomes second nature for those in the discipline but may not be as obvious to novice learners. Take UDL for example. To those of us who are familiar with this approach, the acronym is quite obvious. However, if youve never heard of Universal Design for Learning, UDL might sound strange and confusing. Taking time to clarify discipline-specific symbols, keywords, and acronyms can make it easier for students to focus on understanding the concept, rather than trying to decipher exactly what it is youre talking about. If you arent sure whether or not students know a specific keyword or acronym, ask for a volunteer to explain what it is. That way, you dont need to repeat yourself every time, and students may offer a new way to explain the word or symbol from the novices perspective, rather than your expert explanation. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Highlighting patterns, big ideas, and relationships is a common teaching strategy that many teachers already use. Instead of teaching various distinct concepts, help students make connections between topics by revealing patterns and relationships among them. You can even ask students to attempt to make connections as an activity to check their understanding before providing additional information and clarification on big ideas or patterns. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="All of your content exists within a context. Your course material has a wealth of research and history behind it that your students may not necessarily be aware of. While you dont need to explain the beginning of numbers and letters, it may be useful to explain some of the background behind how a concept was discovered or created or what period of history the course material relates to. Providing additional information helps students lay a foundation of knowledge to build upon once they start using the skills and knowledge you want to teach them. You may also be able to ask students what they already know about a topic to activate their prior knowledge about a concept and build from there. Sometimes students know quite a bit about your topic, and you can start at a higher level of discourse, rather than assuming students dont know the basics. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Expression
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Expression refers to the way students demonstrate their understanding and knowledge. It also includes the HOW of learning -- HOW will students learn and provide evidence of their learning? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Similar to using multiple means for presenting information, you may also consider using multiple mediums and media for communication. HCC students rarely respond to their emails, but they are much more likely to respond to direct messages on Canvas Inbox. You may also communicate with students through text, video, or audio announcements on Canvas, as well as reviewing important housekeeping items during class. Some students have also responded well to instructors who provide a Google Voice number that they can text, since many students are more comfortable with their cell phones than they are with computers or laptops. Providing different avenues for students to communicate makes it more likely that students will reach out to you and respond when you reach out to them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Another important aspect of expression is providing opportunities for choice and autonomy. Instead of dictating the way students must complete a project or assignment, provide a range of choices that students could use to demonstrate their learning. For example, instead of requiring all students to write a 4-page essay on the causes of the civil war, you could allow students to create a video, develop a podcast, create an infographic, or create a presentation. All of these methods would allow you to evaluate students understanding of the causes of the civil war, but they would be free to choose the method of providing that evidence for themselves. This increases their autonomy and gives them the freedom to express their learning in the way that is most comfortable for them. Not everyone will choose to create a video, and many students may still opt to write the traditional essay, but thats their choice, and it may make a big difference for students who do opt for alternative formats. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Students are not always able to accurately assess the amount of time and effort certain assignments will take, and confusion and self-doubt often lead to putting things off until the last minute. You can help guide goal setting, even for minor assignments, by providing an estimated time students should expect to spend working on an assignment or reading. You can also help students evaluate their processes with self-reflection questions on how they approached the task and suggest more efficient ways to work. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Scaffolding is a pedagogical term, which means providing gradually declining support to help students complete a task. When a skill is brand new, students may need more support to get started on their own. Once they start to get the hang of it, you may need to provide nudges to keep them on course. Then, when theyre starting to master the skill, they may only need feedback after performance to help them achieve expert-level nuances in their work. Providing varying levels of support, such as video tutorials, step-by-step guides, and demonstrations, can help give students the confidence they need to try skills on their own. Once they start getting good at it, you can back off a little and provide support only when needed. Providing support for students who need it and letting more proficient students work on their own helps you make the most efficient use of your time, while also giving students the space or support they need to get the job done at their own pace. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Click the X to return to the UDL slide." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
