<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this section, well explore strategies for 3 main instructional activities: lecture, discussion, and group work. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="No matter what subject you teach, you will likely need to facilitate these activities in some form throughout the course of the semester. The strategies in this section will give you a solid foundation for creating engaging active learning opportunities for your students that you can build upon as you continue to experiment with these and other techniques. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the images to view information and instructional strategies about each activity. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the information, a GO button will appear on this slide, which you can use to review what you have learned and test your knowledge with a quiz on this section. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Take a few seconds to think: Why dont students answer when you ask a question in class? What could be the underlying reasons behind the silence during classroom discussions? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youve had some time to think, click GO to continue. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are many possible reasons students dont answer when you ask a question. Lets take a look at a few thoughts students might have when you ask a question. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you ask a question, students may not be confident in their answer and dont want to look stupid if theyre wrong.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For non-native English speakers, students might be self-conscious about their language skills and be nervous about speaking in front of the whole class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Students may also be shy or intimidated by you as an instructor. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="They may not have fully understood the question youre asking but may be shy or scared to ask you to repeat or rephrase it. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Sometimes, our questions may be too obvious, and students might think its either a trick question or wonder why youre asking in the first place. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Many times, students assume that someone else will answer the question, especially if they perceive themselves to be weaker students than other more vocal classmates. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="One of the biggest reasons students dont answer is simply that they dont have enough time to think before the answer is needed. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, many students have learned that if they just wait long enough, the instructor will answer their own question. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="These are just some of the things that may be going on in students heads while you ask a question to start a discussion. Well explore some strategies to prevent this from happening in the next few slides, but what would you do in the moment if you asked a question, and no one answered? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to find out when youre ready." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In order to help you structure your discussions, the acronym PARTS can be used to organize your activity and ensure that you are giving students the necessary time and guidance to participate. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the tabs to learn more about each part of the acronym. Then click BACK to return to the Instructional Strategies slide.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="PRIME 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Before getting into the meat of your discussion, its important to PRIME your students by setting expectations and preparing them to participate in the discussion. Priming introduces students to the topic and helps set expectations for the activity. Priming can occur before class or during class before the discussion. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To prime your students for discussion, have them do a pre-writing activity where you get them thinking about the topic. This could be asking students to brainstorm ideas to solve a problem, answering a few preliminary questions, or defining a few key vocabulary words. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You might also pose a problem or present a scenario and ask students to predict a solution or resolution to the situation. The point here is not for students to guess correctly, but just to think critically about the issue and get them interested in finding out the answer or what comes next. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Priming students may also include having them recall what they already know about the subject. You could ask students to brainstorm everything they know about a concept or give them a few questions to answer together in groups or pairs. Activating prior knowledge prior to the discussion helps students reaffirm the foundation of knowledge, which they will build on during the discussion and lesson. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In order to prepare students to discuss, it may sometimes be necessary to have them read or watch a video to get important context to have an informed discussion. However, instead of just giving students the reading or video clip, make sure to tell students what they should be looking for and what questions they should be able to answer or thinking about during their consumption of the media. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="ASK
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Once you have primed your students for discussion, you can ASK a question. You might ask a couple of questions for students to discuss in a row or repeat the PARTS structure for several larger questions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you ask a question, make sure to display the question on the board, projector, or on a handout so that students can see the question. This helps keep students focused on answering the question or questions you ask and means students dont have to rely on just the auditory instructions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Your questions should also strive to hit the sweet spot between too simple and too complex. Avoid yes/no questions or questions that have a single right answer. Good discussion questions should lend themselves to a variety of answers or perspectives, but they should also not be too complicated that the students cannot answer them. Remember that when you ask a question thats too complex, you can always break it down into simpler, more foundational questions or provide more context to help students understand what youre asking. If you would like to discuss questions that do have a right answer, such as science or math equations, you may facilitate discussion around the process of reaching the answer or approaches to solving the problem. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="It may also be necessary to provide additional context for your question when you ask the question as well as during priming. If discussing a text or video, it may be helpful for students to refer back to the text or re-watch the video during their discussion.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When asking your question, it might be beneficial to frame your content within a scenario or case study. Providing a real-world scenario can encourage your adult learners and motivate them to think more critically about the concept. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="REFLECT
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="After priming students for discussion and asking them the question, give students time to REFLECT before talking with others or sharing out with the whole class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Ask students to think for 30 seconds before calling on students to respond. You should adjust this time depending on the complexity of your question but tell students that you wont accept any answers until after a certain period of time. This lets all of your students know that they will have time to think for themselves and that they dont need to worry about another student answering the question before they have had the chance to process. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another strategy for encouraging reflection is to have students write their answer down on paper or an index card. This acknowledges the fact that some students may be ready to respond before the time is up and allows them to do so without disturbing their classmates. For synchronous online classes, have students type out their answer in the chat but wait to hit the send button. You can also use other tools like Padlet to collect responses anonymously on a separate platform.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In addition to telling students how much time they have to reflect, you can further emphasize wait time by displaying a timer on the screen so that students know how long they have to work out their answer. You can either use the timer built into Google by doing a Google search for Timer or search YouTube for a video timer by searching for 30-second or 1-minute timer. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="TALK
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Once students have had sufficient time to think about their answer, have them TALK to one another before sharing out with the whole class. Doing this gives students the opportunity to further develop their thoughts and correct or clarify misunderstandings.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The tried-and-true technique for getting students to talk is Think-Pair-Share. In this activity, after students have had some time to think, they turn to a partner and share their thoughts. This works great in face-to-face classes for quick interactions. Its also possible to do this in synchronous online classes using breakout rooms, but you may want to use this more sparingly because of the time lost moving between breakout rooms and the main session. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You can also expand this activity by asking pairs of students to join with another pair to further discuss each pairs findings. You can also go directly from reflection into groups of 3 or 4, instead of pairing first. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another way to get students to talk in pairs or groups is to have them write a response to your question on the whiteboard. This gives students a concrete task to do while they discuss to help keep them focused on your question. Once the groups of students have all written their answer on the whiteboard, you can have groups visit another group's board and discuss what the other group has written. They can either write their response directly on the board or check or put an X next to responses they agree or disagree with. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You can replicate this activity online using a shared Google Doc, Slide deck, or Jamboard where students write their responses on the document and then discuss and/or comment on another groups responses.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="SHARE 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Once you have allowed students to talk to each other, you're finally ready to have them SHARE out with the entire class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The easiest way to have students share is to ask for volunteers to share what their group talked about. This may require some rapport-building to make students comfortable enough to volunteer, but if they do feel comfortable, letting students volunteer their own answers provides the least amount of stress and friction for sharing out. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Alternatively, there are several other ways to get students to share out in a more controlled and organized way. You can cold call on students based on conversations you overhear during the talk phase, or if you see an interesting response in one of the groups, you can cold call on a student from the group to share with the rest of the class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If each individual student has something unique to contribute, you may go around the room, having students share out one-by-one. This is not a very common approach, however, since it takes a lot of time to allow each student to share, and students who share first have to wait a long time to contribute anything else to the conversation if they have to wait for their turn to come all the way back around. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Instead of having each student share out, you may go group by group to ask a representative to share what they discussed. This greatly reduces the amount of time it takes to share out but may produce some repetitive answers if groups have similar ideas. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another approach would be to go around, group by group, and ask each group to contribute one new idea. This way, each group has to share something different, and they don't need to share everything they discussed, just one important unique idea. In this case, however, you may need to accept that groups near the end may not have anything additional to contribute that has not already been said, and that's okay. However, make sure that you vary where you start so that the same group doesn't always go last. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="One final idea is to use the jigsaw method, where you start out with a certain number of groups wherein each group is tackling a different scenario or part of a problem. Once the group has discussed and reached a consensus, each group splits off into new groups formed by a single representative from each group that will share what their previous group discussed. Students in each group will take turns sharing what they discussed or teaching their new group what they have learned from their previous group. This technique sometimes takes a little more coordination but can be a great lower stakes way to get students to share out AND increases each individual student's accountability, since every student will be responsible for representing their first group. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="It's important to note that while students are in the talk phase of the discussion, you as the instructor should be walking around the room to different groups or monitoring what groups are saying online. This helps you interrupt misconceptions and mistakes before they get shared out with the rest of the class. It also informs you of good ideas or interesting explanations present within the groups that you can call attention to when asking students to share out. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lecture is one of the oldest and most widely used teaching techniques in existence, but have you ever thought about why we lecture in the first place? For many instructors, it may just be that thats the way they were taught, and they are continuing the tradition of good teaching based on how they themselves learned. However, there are several important benefits that justify the use of this technique besides tradition. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="First, effective lectures allow instructors to provide a lot of information to a lot of people at the same time. This time and effort savings is multiplied when lectures are recorded and can be viewed over and over again by an unlimited amount of learners online. One single lecture can reach millions of learners without any additional effort by the instructor after the lecture has been given. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Perhaps the most cited benefit by instructors and learners alike is that a good lecturer can captivate their audience with their enthusiasm and presentation of their subject. TED Talks and speeches are popular because someone who is enthusiastic about a topic was able to share their passion through their speech, and the same can be true of a good lecture. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lectures are also extremely flexible and can be organized to meet the needs of the audience. Lectures can be planned and adapted before class to fit the needs of particular groups. Even during the lecture itself, if the instructor realizes that a certain point is being misunderstood, they can stop and review it to clarify further. And, if an example or sequence doesnt work as intended, it can be easily rearranged after class and prepared for the next time the lecture is given. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For better or worse, lectures are relatively low- isk for students. For the most part, the instructor is the one in the hot seat during the lecture, and students are free to ask questions as they come up or remain silent and listen. This low-stakes environment may be preferred by students who are shy or nervous about speaking in class, but this means students are also free to daydream, browse social media or even sleep during class, despite our best intentions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, because lecture is so prevalent, there is often an expectation that instructors will lecture, and students may be resistant to different types of instructional strategies, even if they may help them learn and process information better. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In summary, there are legitimate benefits to lecturing, and in the next few slides, well focus on techniques to make sure your lectures are as engaging and effective as possible. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to continue." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Fact or Fiction: Covering material in class during a lecture is sufficient for students to learn it. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click FACT if you think this is a fact, or click FICTION if you think this is fiction. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Fact or Fiction: Project-based learning is always better than lecturing.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click FACT if you think this is a fact, or click FICTION if you think this is fiction. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Fact or Fiction: Students can pay attention for only 10-15 minutes.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click FACT if you think this is a fact, or click FICTION if you think this is fiction. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Fact or Fiction: Its easier to remember things in groups or chunks.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click FACT if you think this is a fact, or click FICTION if you think this is fiction. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Fact or Fiction: A good lecturer must be entertaining.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click FACT if you think this is a fact, or click FICTION if you think this is fiction. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Active lecture techniques give students time to reflect on what they have learned and give you a chance to assess how well students are understanding the material. Here are a few of our favorite activities you can employ between sections of your content. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the techniques to view an explanation of each. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youre finished, click BACK to return to the Instructional Strategies slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Being able to work in a team to accomplish a goal is an essential skill in nearly every discipline and career. Because of this, many faculty choose to incorporate group work into the classroom to help students practice skills such as communication, cooperation, and negotiation. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Before we learn more about how to facilitate groups, lets take a few minutes to do an activity you might use with your classes prior to starting group work to get students engaged and thinking about what makes a group successful. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For this activity, we will use the free website AnswerGarden to create a word cloud. In the text field, type out a characteristic of a well-functioning group and press Enter or click the Submit button next to your answer. This will generate a shared word cloud that will collect all of the answers from you and other colleagues who have already contributed to this activity and display the results, with the most common answers larger in size. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Once you have contributed your characteristics, click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Despite our best efforts to facilitate relevant and engaging group activities, sometimes groups face challenging situations in working together. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="On this slide, you will view 4 challenging scenarios your students may face during group work. Click on each of the students and read the scenario. Then think about what you would do to mitigate or resolve the situation. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Once you have viewed all of the scenarios, a GO button will appear, which will take you to the next slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In order to mitigate the challenges we saw on the previous slide, there are several strategies you can use to make group work more successful. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The first strategy is an overarching theme that well explore more in the next section of the Crash Course, building community. Creating a strong classroom community before doing group work can greatly reduce the amount of issues students have completing their assignments. Its easy to ignore classmates if you have no relationship with them. Students may feel their classmates dont care about them, so it wont bother them to not pull their weight and contribute to the work. However, if students know each other personally and feel connected to one another, its much harder for them to check out of the project and ignore their responsibilities. Group work can actually help you build classroom community, but there needs to be some pre-work done before sending students off into groups for high-stakes projects if they are going to be successful. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another strategy you can use is to have groups create a group contract that they can use to help resolve conflict and take action when things arent working as expected. Having groups or the entire class think about, decide, and agree to policies and procedures regarding what to do when one student doesnt do their work or if there is a disagreement between members can provide structure for dealing with challenges before they occur, and letting students know the consequences or outcomes of their actions up-front can help keep them more accountable to each other. Have a discussion with your class about what effective groups do and how they should approach common pitfalls and scenarios like the ones we saw on the previous slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In order to make sure work is split evenly and all students can participate and contribute to the group, it may be helpful to incorporate individual assignments prior to putting students into groups. For example, if you would like students to put together a research presentation, let students work individually first to do their own research and have them submit it to you online or in person. Then, when you group students, each member will have their own research to contribute and will be able to add to the presentation based on the work they did individually. This is just one example of individual accountability, but anything you can assign students prior to going into groups can help mitigate free-riders or dominating group members.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Providing students the rubric you will use to grade them helps clarify the expectations and requirements of the project, while also mitigating some of the challenges students may have when deciding how to fulfill those requirements. Walk students through the rubric and consider having students use the rubric to grade their own project prior to submitting. This will help ensure students have thoroughly read the rubric, while also reducing your grading time. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If you are facilitating a larger group project, you may consider incorporating a way for students to leave a dysfunctional group. There are several approaches to this, such as allowing anyone in the class who wants to change groups at a certain point in the project to form new groups or work on their own. You may also give groups the power to "fire" a group member if they are absent or not contributing as much as they should be. The fired group member will then need to get hired by a new group or complete the project on their own. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="However, firing shouldn't be the first response to dysfunction. Require levels of mediation to work out issues so that students can attempt to resolve their problems before having to fire a group member. Examples of mediation would include having to contact a group member by two different methods, such as by email and by phone, before bringing it to the instructor's attention. If the student cannot be reached or doesn't change, the instructor should be a second tier of mediation to attempt to resolve the challenges the group is having. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="An alternative to firing a group member is to incorporate peer evaluations, so that members who did not pull their weight have consequences, and the group members who are unsatisfied with their classmate's performance have an outlet to voice their complaints. You may consider either taking points from the non-contributing student and adding it to the other students or grading the students who did put in the effort based on their contributions, even though the project as a whole may not be complete. Consider providing peer evaluation criteria to students so that they rate their peers on their effort, contributions, and communication, rather than their own personal feelings or biases. You may also consider providing open ended ratings instead of numerical ratings. By doing this, you can have students explain what each group member contributed and why they rated them the way they did and avoid collusion between group members and mitigate bias. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Although there are many strategies here that effectively break up the group to form new groups, don't forget that one of the goals of group work is to give students relevant skills in conflict resolution and teamwork. Whenever possible, keeping the group together and helping students work out their own issues will better prepare them for the real world and help them hone these skills.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="As the use of video conferencing software like Zoom increases, you may find yourself facilitating more of your group work online in real time through the use of breakout rooms. Here are a few strategies to help you make these sessions more engaging and impactful. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The most important strategy for effective breakout rooms is to assign a deliverable. Require students to write something down or contribute to a document so that when you return to the main session and share out, each group has something they can contribute. This also helps students stay focused during the duration of the breakout session and instills a little more urgency in getting the task done, rather than veering off topic. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="One way you can keep students focused and organize is to use Google Docs, Slides, Jamboard, or another collaborative online tool so that students can all contribute to the same document. Students are able to share their screen in the breakout session, but using a shareable document allows each group member to be able to see and contribute to the task on their own screen. You can create a document for each group or have all of the groups contribute to the same document, either by directly editing the document itself or commenting on the side. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="As students are working, be sure to check into each breakout room to see how things are going. Remind students that they can contact you by using the Ask for Help button on Zoom and that you will join their room as soon as you can. If you are using collaborative tools like Google Docs to facilitate your breakout room session activities, you can also look at the document and see what students are working on without disturbing their room. If a group seems to be stuck or hasnt written anything down, you can join their room and check in to see whats happening. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Although some students cannot use their camera because of poor internet connections or because they are sharing their space with others, encourage students who can use their camera to turn it on. Students may feel less intimidated to turn on their camera in breakout sessions since there are only a few other people in the room compared to in the main meeting room where everyone in the class is watching. As students get to know each other and begin to build trust, they may be more likely to show themselves on camera, which can further increase the sense of community and belonging in your class. However, remember that there are legitimate reasons students cannot use their camera, and you should not enforce this as a rule.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you send students into breakout rooms, before having them tackle a problem, case study, or discuss a question, incorporate a no-stakes icebreaker that allows students to get to know each other better. You may consider doing this throughout the semester to continue to foster conversation and informal discussion among students, since they normally cannot have the side conversations and before and after class chat that they would have in the face-to-face environment. Although they may seem unrelated to your content or teaching practice, these informal conversations help build community and trust between students, which makes it more likely that they will work together better and less likely that they will check out and leave their group out to dry.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to view some examples of icebreakers you can use with your students. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are many different icebreakers you can use to help students get to know each other and build community and trust in your classroom. Click on the tabs to the left to view a description of each of the icebreakers on this slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youre finished, click the BACK button to return to the Instructional Strategies slide. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="True or False: You should require students to turn on their camera during breakout room sessions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If you find yourself running out of time during a lecture, what is the best thing to do?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Which of the following are the PARTS of an active discussion?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Which of the following is NOT a benefit of lecturing?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="What can you do to mitigate the ability for students to be a free-rider during group work?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Select your answer, then click SUBMIT." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Congratulations!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You have completed this section of the New Faculty Crash Course! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to view the next section on Classroom Community! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this section, you will learn how to build classroom community and review strategies to deal with challenging student behavior through preventative and responsive techniques. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Creating a strong sense of community in the classroom can make your instructional strategies more effective and make the teaching and learning experience smoother overall. Although many of these strategies do not directly relate to the subject matter you are teaching, its worth taking the time to use these strategies and techniques to build community to make your classes more engaging and effective for students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the images to view information about each topic. When youve viewed all of the information, a GO button will appear, which you can use to view a summary of what you have learned and test your knowledge with a quiz on this section." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="What is classroom community? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Strong communities have members who have shared goals and experiences, who feel empowered to contribute, who trust in one another, and who feel understood and capable as individuals. These attributes enable teamwork, cooperation, a willingness to negotiate, and the ability to draw on one anothers skills. (Kane, 2016)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Classroom community is made up of 2 parts: student emotions and the learning experience as a whole. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="In a strong classroom community, students should feel respected by both the instructor and their peers. They should feel that they belong in the class and that they need to be there. They should have a positive attitude towards learning and believe that they can succeed in the class. And finally, they should feel that the content is personally relevant to them and their current or future needs. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="The learning experience also plays a big role in creating a strong classroom community and should be challenging without feeling impossible. It should include the students perspective and encourage students to think and behave like professionals in the field. It should be valuable and not just transactional; the students should feel that they are doing the work for themselves, not just to hand in to the instructor for a grade. And finally, the learning experience should be as authentic as possible, including things like real-world scenarios and tackling real-world problems. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Sound familiar? Many of these elements of classroom community overlap with the principles of adult learning theory and active learning strategies. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style> <ListStyle ListType="None" BulletChar="" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more about how to create classroom community. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="One of the biggest factors in creating a strong classroom community is building a sense of belonging. This is challenging because it depends on each students emotional connection to the class, which is rarely ever stated concretely and is usually not visibly evident. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Here are 4 of the main features that play a role in whether or not a student feels that they belong in your classroom. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on the tabs at the top of the screen to learn more about each of the features.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Inclusion
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Part of fostering a sense of belonging is to make sure that you are creating an inclusive environment for diverse perspectives and ideas. Inclusion means that everyone in the class has the right to voice their opinion and share their thoughts and that discussion and debate are managed appropriately, entertaining different ideas and viewpoints, without attacking the person with those viewpoints. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To create an inclusive environment, start off by getting students to talk to each other through icebreakers. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You can also encourage students to post a picture of themselves online on Canvas with and without a mask on so that you can get to know what the student looks like under the mask but still recognize them with a mask on. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You may also set some ground rules for the semester by creating a collaborative classroom contract, where you define expectations for sharing ideas, respecting classmates, accountability in group work, and more. Click the Example link to view a sample classroom contract. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Along with creating a classroom contract, you might also set some expectations and ground rules before beginning a discussion, especially if you will be discussing sensitive or potentially triggering topics. Remind students that they are all there to learn, and different opinions should be welcomed and discussed, rather than attacked or shut down. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, to further emphasize the fact that you want to explore differing viewpoints, encourage and highlight different perspectives. When students post something online or mention something during group work, you may call attention to it to further discuss it or bring more awareness to it for the rest of the class. Even just telling students that you appreciate their perspectives and ideas can help make students feel more comfortable sharing with the class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Attitude
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="A positive attitude towards learning helps motivate students and is another important factor in making students feel welcome in the class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To help students feel more positive about their learning experience, emphasize relevance and show students how your course content relates to the real world and how it plays a role in their lives. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Whenever possible, provide students opportunities to exercise choice in what they learn, how they learn, and how they demonstrate their understanding. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Provide encouragement and tell students that you want them to succeed and believe that they can learn your course content. While this may seem obvious to us, telling students that you believe that they can succeed and you want to help them do so can do a lot to impact their attitude towards your course. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally, treat your students like professionals and encourage them to think and behave like a biologist or an author or a sociologist. Encouraging them to think of themselves as a professional also builds their confidence and self-efficacy as they tackle challenging problems within the discipline. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Meaning
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Your course should be personally meaningful to students and provide challenging work for students to wrestle with. Similar to authentic instruction, creating meaningful learning opportunities motivates adult learners to care about your course. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While we should provide challenging assignments and problems for students to work through, we also need to support them when they get stuck. Providing support only when students need it allows them to try to work out the solution on their own but reassures them that you will help guide them if they get off track or are not sure how to proceed. This support paired with encouragement shows that you mean what you say when you tell them you want to help them succeed. Remind students that everyone is there to learn, and they can always ask for help when they need it. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Use case studies and scenarios to frame real-world problems and provide opportunities for reflection so that students can think about what they are learning and how it relates to themselves and the world around them. Consider building questions into assignments that get students to think about what they have done and how it can be used.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Competence
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Students need support, encouragement, and inclusion, but they also need to feel competent in their own abilities if they can truly feel they belong in your course. If a student is supported and encouraged but does not believe or see that they can actually do what youre asking, they may feel like a fraud or that everyone else gets it except for them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To help build competence and confidence, facilitate low-stakes assessment often. Consider using mobile quizzing apps like Quizizz or allowing students to answer questions without being graded. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you provide feedback, make sure to point out students' strengths, while also recommending some areas for improvement. It's important to provide positive feedback as well as giving actionable feedback where students can improve so that they can see their own progress as well as know what to change to get better. Pointing out failure alone without giving suggestions for how to improve can further damage students' sense of competence. Consider building current events into assignments and discussion to allow students to start discipline-focused conversations with their own friends and family members. Being able to concretely point out or explain something they learned in class and how it relates to a current event can give them some social capital and boost their self-esteem outside of class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally, encourage students to relate content to real-world applications. Have students make connections and think about how the concepts you discuss in class are used in the real world. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are several things students do that you might feel are challenging behaviors. Take a moment to think about a few behaviors and enter them into the Answer Garden on this slide by typing out the behavior and pressing Enter. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youre finished, click GO to continue. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Students may do many things that we as instructors interpret as challenging behavior. Some of these behaviors may include when students dominate a conversation, when they come late to class, when they dont listen or follow instructions, when they disrupt class, and when they are distracted or daydreaming or even sleeping. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="However, as instructors, we also have reactions to these behaviors. We may feel angry, curious, affronted, annoyed, empathetic, patient, or any number of other emotions, and all of these are valid. That being said, our reaction to these challenging behaviors can greatly impact our relationship with our students, both those who are doing the thing we find challenging, as well as the rest of the students in the class who are observing the situation and our reactions. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The Student-Faculty Behavior Cycle starts with a student behavior. A student does something that we find to be challenging or unexpected. Then, we as a faculty member have an emotional reaction to that behavior. Sometimes its surprise. Sometimes its anger. Sometimes its confusion. However, our response to both the behavior and the emotion must be carefully executed so that we dont alienate the student who is doing the behavior but also be done in such a way that it addresses the situation and does not detract from the lesson or learning experience of other students. Depending on our response to the situation, the student who did the challenging behavior will have an emotional response to our behavioral response. They may feel offended, relieved, or just as confused as we are. Then finally, the student has another behavioral response, and the cycle starts over again. If we handle the situation well, the students next behavior will be positive and will resolve the situation. However, if our response is not appropriate, the students next behavior may be worse or unexpected again. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While all of this is playing out with the single student with the challenging behavior, the other 23 (or more) students in your class are watching and may also be having their own personal emotional response to your response to the student. Sometimes, they may feel relieved that you are addressing a disruptive student, but other times they may feel you were overly harsh to a student or were too lax in your response. While its not possible to know how each interaction is affecting each individual student, there are some strategies you can use to address challenging behaviors so that you can continue to have a positive relationship with your students but do not lose tons of class time to disruptions or distraction. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click GO to learn more. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are two main categories of strategies for dealing with challenging behavior: preventative strategies and responsive strategies. Click on each of the tabs to learn more about what you can do to prevent challenging behaviors and what you can do in the moment to address them. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you have viewed all of the strategies, click the GO button to view some real-world scenarios of challenging behaviors.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Preventative
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Building a strong sense of community is the best preventative measure to avoid challenging behaviors in the first place. Building a sense of respect and understanding can drastically reduce the frequency of these behaviors, but here are some additional strategies you can use to build community and prevent unwanted behaviors. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Greet students every class period and use their names when you do. For larger classes or when there is little time between classes, this is not always possible, but whenever you can, greet even just a few students each class. This can help build a stronger relationship between you and your students and increase rapport. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Posting agenda can also help students who may be nervous about what they are going to have to do in your class and can also warn shy or anxious students about upcoming group work, assessments, or discussions and prime them for those activities. You may also want to point out changes or new activities to give students a heads up about something different they will be asked to do during or after class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Create a class rhythm so that students know what to expect when they come to your class. This could be starting with a certain activity, icebreaker, or review and following with a mini-lecture and discussion or any number of instructional strategies. However, make sure that you vary the types of activities you do so your class doesnt feel stale or not worthwhile for students to attend. Strike a balance between consistency and variation so that students can have a sense of what to expect but always know something is going to be different and feel they will be missing something important if they dont come to class. An example of this would be that even though you may always start class with some sort of review of the homework, the type of activity you use to review is never the same as last class. One time, you might do a think-pair-share activity, another might be to play a Quizizz game, and another might be an individual pop quiz. Although the activities are effectively accomplishing the same purpose, they are giving students some variation and sense of novelty.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Consider chunking assignments and including check-points so that students don't get too far behind or off track with larger projects. Create stop-points where students need to turn something in or discuss with you or a peer so that you can put them back on track before they get lost or check out entirely. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another simple strategy is to share regular announcements and reach out to students frequently on Canvas. Creating consistent lines of dialogue with students can help build rapport and strengthen connections to your class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="And finally, consider requiring students to attend at least one "student hour" meeting with you throughout the semester. Making this either a graded assignment or for extra credit can help you get to know your students better and limit the likelihood of students dropping off or misbehaving in the classroom.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Responsive
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="It's definitely better to prevent challenging behavior from occurring, but when it does occur, there are certain things you should do in the moment to make sure you can continue teaching without derailing the entire class period, while also maintaining a level of respect and rapport with students. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="First, get close to the behavior. Use proximity to let students know you are aware of the behavior and give them a chance to correct themselves without putting them on the spot or drawing any attention to them. This is by far the best thing to do because it immediately lets the student know you noticed them, but it doesn't shame or embarrass them, allowing you to keep a good relationship with the student.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If you notice that a student is consistently coming late to class and is disrupting the class by walking through to the back of the classroom, tell students to leave a couple of seats open by the door so that students who are coming late can come in quickly and sit down without interrupting the activity in the room. You should follow up with the student later so that you can see what's going on and let them know that you'll leave the seat open for them when they come in, so that they don't disrupt the rest of the class. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Sometimes, if a challenging behavior is repeated, you can try to identify the ABCs: The Antecedent - What may be causing this behavior? The Behavior itself - What the student is doing that is not appropriate. And the Consequence - What can you do to mitigate this behavior? Talk to the student and let them know you noticed the behavior and ask if there is anything you or the student can do to help or limit the behavior.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="One strategy to limit challenging behaviors is to create a signal with students. Sometimes disruptive students don't realize they are being disruptive, so creating a signal like a wink or putting your hand on the desk of the student can acknowledge them without calling them out or shutting them down. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Remember that you don't need to be the expert here and that you can reach out to Disability Support Services or your coordinator or supervisor for help. Safety is the number one priority, so it's important to address any dangerous behaviors immediately, so if you aren't sure what to do, ask for help. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally, the most important responsive strategy is to begin again the next class with a clean slate. Don't hold anything against the student and make sure to greet them specifically when they come in to show them that you aren't holding a grudge. This strategy is essential in keeping a positive relationship with the student and to prevent the behavior from getting worse." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Now lets put your instincts to the test! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on each of the students and read the scenario. For each scenario, think about what you could do in the moment to respond to the behavior and what you might do after class or during the next class to mitigate the behavior in the future. Then click the GO button, which will appear after youve reviewed all of the scenarios, to hear additional ideas for how to respond to the behaviors. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Remember that maintaining a polite and professional level of communication with students is the most effective way to deal with challenging behavior without destroying the rapport you have built with your students. You need to address these behaviors so that they dont get worse, but you should do so in a way that doesnt create an adversarial relationship between you and the student. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Think about a student who has been challenging to you, or if you dont have one in mind, think about which student would be the most challenging in the scenarios we just reviewed. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Identify the behavior that is challenging and what emotions or factors might be causing that behavior. Consider how the behavior makes you feel but try to take an objective approach to responding to the challenge so that you can maintain a positive relationship with the student, while still addressing the behavior. Finally, think about what else you might want to know about the student. It might not be appropriate to ask the student directly, but you can always state that you have noticed the specific behavior, explain why it is inappropriate, and tell them you would like to help them or find ways to avoid the behavior in the future. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Draft an email or Canvas message to the student where you identify the behavior, ask for more information, and show support. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When youre finished, click BACK to return to the Classroom Community slide. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Congratulations!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You have completed the New Faculty Crash Course! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the EVALUATION button to complete an evaluation and final synthesis activity where you will be asked to answer 5 out of 10 total questions to demonstrate what you have learned about the content within this crash course.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Then, you will be asked to provide some feedback on your experience with this course. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Upon the completion of the evaluation, you will receive an index number, which you can use to register to earn PD credit for this course. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If you have any questions on concerns, please contact IMFacultyLab@howardcc.edu for assistance or more information.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click the RETRY button to take the quiz again. You must get at least 60% to pass. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
